title: Trying to make a font
content:
I’m trying to make my first font. Apparently the only free way to make fonts is through FontForge which I’m having a hard time using. I’ve already designed all the basic letter in Inkscape but they always come out with the wrong spacing and wrong height. Also, when I try to save I always get errors on the letters which ruin the design. Can someone help me with this? I tried really hard.

Here is the font I’m try to make.  
 [http://willhostforfood.com/users/M/mega\_rock\_exe/BN\_Title\_font.svg](http://web.archive.org/web/20091001030331/http:/willhostforfood.com/users/M/mega_rock_exe/BN_Title_font.svg "http://willhostforfood.com/users/M/mega\_rock\_exe/BN\_Title\_font.svg")
author: Koetsu

comments.content:
Hi Koetsu,

Get FontLab and start using it:

[http://www.fontlab.com/font-editor/fontlab-studio/](http://web.archive.org/web/20091001030331/http:/www.fontlab.com/font-editor/fontlab-studio/ "http://www.fontlab.com/font-editor/fontlab-studio/")

Also get the book ’Learn FontLab Fast by Leslie Cabarga’:

[http://www.amazon.co.uk/s/ref=nb\_ss?url=search-alias%3Dstripbooks&field-...](http://web.archive.org/web/20091001030331/http:/www.amazon.co.uk/s/ref=nb_ss?url=search-alias%3Dstripbooks&field-keywords=Fontlab&x=0&y=0 "http://www.amazon.co.uk/s/ref=nb\_ss?url=search-alias%3Dstripbooks&field-keywords=Fontlab&x=0&y=0")

Cheers
Karen Cheng’s book “designing type” is also a must.

Making fonts is a long and difficult process.  
 [http://www.google.com/search?rls=en&q=fontforge+tutorial&ie=UTF-8&oe=UTF...](http://web.archive.org/web/20091001030331/http:/www.google.com/search?rls=en&q=fontforge+tutorial&ie=UTF-8&oe=UTF-8 "http://www.google.com/search?rls=en&q=fontforge+tutorial&ie=UTF-8&oe=UTF-8")

I think here on Typophile you can find useful help for more specific problems.

<cite>Karen Cheng’s book “designing type” is also a must.</cite>

A must what? Certainly not a must have.

[Briem’s online tutorial](http://web.archive.org/web/20091001030331/http:/briem.net/) is IMHO the best place to start. Letters of Credit by Walter Tracy is extremely helpful, as is Cabaraga’s Learn FontLab fast. I learned a lot from Fonts & Logos by Doyald Young. Karen Cheng’s book is not a must have, though it has helpful comparisons of different fonts. The most important things are to study other fonts you admire in a font drawing program, see how they work on paper and screen, and draw, draw, draw.
But I have the letters done. I just need to make it into a usable file. I’ll try FontLab.

Or get [TypeTool](http://web.archive.org/web/20091001030331/http:/www.fontlab.com/font-editor/typetool/) instead. It’s a lot less daunting — and cheaper — than FontLab, especially for someone making their first font.

I can’t use these, unfortunately. I don’t have any income. I can’t purchase software for one font. This is actually the only font I need to make. Seems like too much of a hassle to get it and make the font and it isn’t worth it.

If anyone wants to make it, by all means go ahead. I can’t spend so much time on this anymore.
